raw_text:
Gadgets galore on show at fair
 
 The 2005 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is a geek's paradise with more than 50,000 new gadgets and technologies launched during the four-day event.
 
 Top gadgets at the show are highlighted in the Innovations Showcase, which recognises some of the hottest developments in consumer electronics. The BBC News website took an early pre-show look at some of those technologies that will be making their debut in 2005. 
 
  
 
 One of the key issues for keen gadget users is how to store all their digital images, audio and video files. The 2.5GB and 5GB circular pocket hard drive from Seagate might help. The external USB drive won a CES best innovations design and engineering award and is small enough to slip into a pocket. "It is the kind of storage that appeals to people who want their PCs to look cool," said Seagate. "It is all about style but it also has lots of functionality." "It is the first time you can say a hard drive is sexy," it said. In the centre of the device is a blue light that flashes while data is being written to ensure users do not unplug it when it is busy saving those precious pictures. 
 
  
 
 Universal Electronics' NevoSL is a universal controller that lets people use one device to get at their multimedia content, such as photos, no matter where it is in their house. It can also act as a remote for home theatre and stereo systems. Working with home broadband networks and PCs, the gadget has built-in wireless and a colourful, simple interface. Paul Arling, UEI chief, said consumers face real problems when trying to get at all the files they own that are typically spread across several different devices. He said the Nevo gave people a simple, single way to regain some control over digital media in the home. The Nevo won two awards at CES, one as a Girl's Best Friend award and another for innovation, design and engineering. The gadget is expected to go on sale before the summer and will cost about $799 (£425). 
 
  
 
 Hotseat is targeting keen gamers with money to spend with its Solo Chassis gaming chair. The specially-designed chair lets gamers play in surround-sound while stretching out in their own "space". It is compatible with all the major games consoles, DVD players and PCs. "We found that kids love playing in surround sound," said Jay LeBoff from Hotseat. "We are looking at offering different types of seats, depending on the market success of this one." The chair also lets people experience surround sound while watching videos, with wireless control for six surround sound speakers. And a drinks holder. The chair, which looks like a car seat on a skeletal frame, should go on sale in April and is expected to cost $399 (£211). 
 
  
 
 Satellite radio is big business in the US. In the UK, the digital radio technology is known as DAB and works on slightly different technology. Eton Corporation's Porsche designed P7131 digital radio set will be launched both as a DAB radio in the UK as well as a satellite radio set in the US. DAB sets have been slow to take-off in the UK, but this one concentrates on sleek looks as much as technology. "It is for the risqué consumer," said an Eton spokesperson. "We are proud of it because it has the sound quality for the audiophile and the looks for the design-conscious consumer." The Porsche radio is set to go on sale at the end of January in the US and in the first quarter of 2005 in the UK. In the US is it expected to cost $250 (£133). 
 
  
 
 The average person has a library of 600 digital images estimates the Consumer Electronics Association, the organisation behind CES. This is expected to grow to a massive 3,420 images - or 7.2GB - in five years' time. One gadget that might help swell that collection is Sanyo's tiny handheld VPC-C4 camcorder which is another innovation in design and engineering award winner. It combines high quality video and stills in a very small device. It takes MPEG4 video quality at 30 frames a second and has a four megapixel still camera. Images and video are stored on SD cards, which have come down in price in recent months. A 512MB card will store about 30 minutes of video and 420 stills. The device is so tiny it can be controlled with one thumb. Because images and video are stored on SD memory, it is portable to other devices and means other data like audio can be stored on the card too. 
 
  
 
 Wearable technology has always promised much but failed to deliver because of lack of storage capability and poor design. MPIO's tiny digital USB music players come in an array of fashionable colours, taking a leaf out of the Apple iPod mini book of design and reflecting the desire for gadgets that look good. Slung on a cord, the player would not look too geeky dangling discreetly from the neck. Although the pendant design was launched three months ago, the device emphasises large storage as well as good looks for fashion-conscious gadget fiends. An even dinkier model, the FY500, comes out in May and will store about 256MB of music. The range of players recently won an International Forum design award 2005.
llama3.2:1b:
The text describes various gadgets that will be launched at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas, including:

- A 2.5GB or 5GB circular pocket hard drive from Seagate
- An external USB drive that has been awarded a CES best innovations design and engineering award
- A universal controller called NevoSL from Universal Electronics that allows users to access multimedia content across devices
- A gaming chair called Hotseat from Hotseat that features surround sound capabilities and wireless control for video playback
- Satellite radio, which is available in the US as DAB and satellite technology
- A handheld VPC-C4 camcorder from Sanyo that combines high-quality video and stills storage on SD cards
- Tiny digital USB music players called MPIO from MPIO that offer large storage capacity and fashionable designs.
llama3.2:3b: Seagate's circular pocket hard drive can store up to 2.5GB or 5GB digital files; Universal Electronics' NevoSL is a universal controller for multimedia content; Hotseat's Solo Chassis gaming chair offers surround sound and wireless control; Eton Corporation's Porsche designed P7131 digital radio set features sleek design and high sound quality; Sanyo's VPC-C4 camcorder has high-quality video and stills in a tiny device; MPIO's wearable USB music players come in fashionable colors with large storage options.
gemma2:2b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) showcased a plethora of new gadgets.
Seagate's pocket hard drive won awards for its stylish design, while Universal Electronics' NevoSL offers central control over multimedia content in the home.
Hotseat's Solo Chassis gaming chair combines surround sound and stretching space.
Eton Corporation's P7131 digital radio set targets audiophiles and design-conscious consumers with sleek looks.
Sanyo's tiny camcorder delivers high quality video and stills on portable SD cards.
MPIO's USB music players prioritize stylish design and large storage capacity.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas showcased a variety of new gadgets and technologies, including Seagate's USB flash drive and Universal Electronics' NevoSL gaming chair.
Both products were aimed at users who want easy access to their media content and improved video playback, respectively.
In addition, Sanyo's VPC-C4 camcorder combined high quality video and stills in a small device for portable storage.
Wearable technology was also discussed with MPIO introducing a mini-device featuring digital music players that store up to 256MB of media.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The 2005 Consumer Electronics Show features over 50,000 new gadgets and technologies showcasing innovations such as Seagate's circular pocket hard drive, Universal Electronics' NevoSL universal controller, Hotseat's gaming chair, Eton Corporation's Porsche-designed digital radio set, Sanyo's handheld camcorder, MPIO's USB music player, and others.
These products aim to address specific consumer needs in areas like storage, gaming, media management, and fashionable technology design.
qwen2.5:3b: The 2005 Consumer Electronics Show featured over 50,000 new gadgets and technologies.

Key highlights include:

- Seagate's 2.5GB and 5GB circular pocket hard drive, which wins best innovation awards for style and functionality.
- Universal Electronics' NevoSL universal controller to manage multimedia content across various devices.
- Hotseat’s Solo Chassis gaming chair designed for gamers with surround-sound capabilities and wireless control.
- Eton Corporation's Porsche-designed P7131 digital radio set launching both in the US (satellite) and UK (DAB), praised for looks over technology.
- Sanyo's VPC-C4 camcorder, a design award winner offering high-quality video and still photography stored on SD cards.
- MPIO’s digital USB music players, now including smaller FY500 models with 256MB storage in fashionable designs.
opencoder:1.5b:
A summary of the text is: 

The 4-day Consumer Electronics Show will feature gadgets at Las Vegas to bring a geek's paradise where tech enthusiasts can enjoy, save and share their digital images, audio and video files.
The Seagate external USB drive won awards for innovative design and engineering, with Universal Electronics' NevoSL making it accessible to everyone who is a gadget lover.
Hotseat's Solo Chassis gaming chair will provide a unique gaming experience in the comfort of your home.
The DAB radio technology from Eton Corporation will be a part of the UK, while satellite radio set will be available worldwide for consumers on the US market.
The collection of 600 digital images is expected to grow rapidly and can reach a massive size in 5 years time.
A P7131 digital VPC-C4 camcorder gadget will help in storing high-quality video and stills with ease, while an image card for music will be available.
smollm:1.7b: The article highlights several key issues for keen gadget users: how to store all their digital images, audio and video files; the need for style but functionality in gadgets; the importance of good design and engineering in gadgets; the potential for gadgets to make people's lives easier by automating tasks or providing entertainment.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: 2005 CES Show in Las Vegas featured over 50,000 gadgets at the Innovations Showcase.
Highlighted were Seagate SD cards, Universal and Seagate awards.
Hotseat targeting gamers with the Solo Chassis chair.
P7131 Porsche radio with DAB vs. satellite radio in US and UK.
Sanyo VPC-C4 for small video storage, MPIO digital music players with design award wins.
tinyllama:1.1b: The Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas is highlighted with several gaudy, colorful, and high-tech devices showcasing innovations in consumer electronics.

Some notable exhibits include the Eton Corporation's Porsche designed P7131 digital radio set which has a sleek design and focuses on sound quality for audio enthusiasts, and Sanyo's tiny handheld VPC-C4 camcorders which have a high-quality video quality of 30 frames per second and a four megapixel still camera.

The Innovations Showcase recognizes innovative developments in consumer electronics that will be making their debut in 2005, while the BBC News website took an early pre-show look at some of those technologies that will be making their debut in 2005.

Other notable exhibits include Universal Electronics' NevroSL, which is a universal controller for gaming consoles and home theatre systems, and Seagate's "Hotseat," which is designed to connect game consoles with DVD players and PCs.

The company also showcases the Solo Chaixis gamers chair that allows them to play in surround sound, while Hotseat offers gamers a seat for watching video games, DVDs, and more on a sleek, wireless-controlled device called the "Porsche designed P7131."

The UK's Digital Radio Technology Association (DRA) showcases their new DAAB technology for satellite radio, which works with digital audio broadcasting to provide users with high-quality audio while watching videos and enjoying satellite radio.

Other notable exhibits include Sony's 600-image library of digital images in a tiny handheld camcorder, Sanyo's VPC-C4 digital camcorders, and Apple Inc.'s iPod mini, which reflects the desire for gaudy designs while still delivering high storage capacity.
tinydolphin:1.1b: In summary, the text provides an overview of notable gadgets at the 2005 Consumer Electronics Show (CES), highlighting some key innovations and advancements in consumer electronics such as: 1) the launch of Seagate's 2.5GB and 5GB circular pocket hard drive; 2) the launch of Eton Corporation's Porsche-designed P7131 digital radio set, featuring a unique focus on sleek design and technology; 3) the introduction of the VPC-C4 camcorder from Sanyo with high quality video and still images in a compact, portable form factor; 4) the launch of Wearable Technology companies like Wearable Technology Player (MPIO), which incorporates fashionable designs, large storage capacities, and good looks for gadget fiends.

Seagate introduced a 2.5GB and 5GB circular pocket hard drive that was designed to look cool and function well, winning a CES best innovations design and engineering award.

granite3.1-dense:2b: The 2005 Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas showcases over 50,000 new gadgets and technologies.
Seagate's circular pocket hard drives (2.5GB and 5GB) won a CES best innovations design award for their compact size and stylish appearance.
They feature blue lights that indicate data writing, preventing users from unplugging them during operations.
Universal Electronics' NevoSL is a universal controller that allows users to access multimedia content across various devices with a single gadget.
It supports home broadband networks, PCs, and home theater systems.
The Nevo won two awards for its innovative design, simplicity, and functionality.
Priced at $799 (£425), it's expected to launch before summer 2005.
Hotseat's Solo Chassis gaming chair offers surround sound for gamers while they play on major consoles, DVD players, and PCs.
Compatible with all major gaming platforms, the chair features a drinks holder and wireless control for six surround-sound speakers.
Expected to cost $399 (£211), it's set to launch in April 2005.

Eton Corporation's Porsche P7131 digital radio, both DAB and satellite-capable, combines sleek design with superior sound quality for audiophiles and appealing aesthetics for the fashion-conscious consumer.
Available in the US at the end of January 2005 and in the UK in early 2005, it is expected to retail for $250 (£133).
Sanyo's VPC-C4 camcorder won a design and engineering award for its compact size and high-quality video and stills capabilities at 30 frames per second and four megapixels, respectively.
Images and videos are stored on SD cards, which are becoming more affordable, with a 512MB card holding about 30 minutes of video and 420 stills.
MPIO's line of fashionable digital USB music players, inspired by the iPod mini, has garnered an International Forum design award for 2005.
They come in various colors, store up to 256MB of music on SD cards, and can be discreetly worn as necklaces.
The even smaller FY500 model will launch in May 2005.
